alert.note: Alert for Franklin; Hart; Stephens (Georgia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 27 at 12:09AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 315 AM EDT EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia and upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, in northeast Georgia, Franklin, Hart and Stephens. In upstate South Carolina, Anderson and Oconee. * WHEN...Until 315 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1206 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to torrential showers and thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen over the past two hours and an additional inch of rain is possible in some locations through 2 am EDT. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Toccoa, Carnesville, Reed Creek, Lavonia, Gumlog, Canon, Bowersville, Martin, Avalon, Tugaloo State Park, Lake Hartwell, Fair Play, Oakway, Eastanolee and Townville. Flooding is most likely along Cleveland Creek, Beaverdam Creek, and tributaries to Lake Hartwell. Additional flooding is possible along Eastanollee Creek, Toms Creek, and Clarks Creek. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
